newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile's Aninat and Central Bank agree on '97 goals.
newsitem.headline: Chile's Aninat and Central Bank agree on '97 goals.

text.p: Finance Minister Eduardo Aninat signalled that the economic targets contained in Chile's 1997 budget will be similar to those set this month by the Central Bank.
Aninat, in a published interview, said the Central Bank and the Finance Ministry had agreed on basic outlines for the 1997 targets which both institutions present to Congress.

The Central Bank this month forecast 5.5 percent inflation and 5.5-to-6.0 percent growth in the gross domestic product next year, both down from expected 6.5 percent inflation and seven percent GDP growth this year.
Aninat will give his own targets in early October.

"We agree fully with those targets, and when I make the Public Finances presentation in the first week of October, I will add precision to those and other goals," said Aninat in an interview in the financial daily El Diario.
"There was a very fluid process of weekly communications (between the bank and the ministry) to agree on a common and equal diagnosis in terms of the 1997 scenario," he said.
Aninat also said Chile and Canada were about four weeks away from finishing talks for a free trade agreement.
"We're about to reach, in the next four weeks I hope, an agreement with Canada," he said.
Officials of both nations said recently they were confident they could sign a free trade pact, similar to that between Chile and Mexico, by the end of the year.
But Chile's long-standing wish to join the North American Free Trade Agreement has been sidetracked by the U.S. elections, said Aninat.
"It takes two to tango, and one of those partners is now busy with another task: the elections," he said.
Both President Bill Clinton and his predecessor George Bush have invited Chile to join NAFTA, but U.S. domestic politics have prevented full-scale negotiations from getting underway.
Aninat said Chileans need not forget about NAFTA, but added that Chile's entrance into it has not gone "at the speed that the government wanted."
